Expectation1: Look out for each other's safety and well-being
Situation1: The siblings are walking home from school together on a familiar street.
Expectation2: Ensure client satisfaction and address any concerns or complaints professionally
Situation2: A first-time visitor looks disappointed with the colour tone in the mirror.
Story: I was walking home from school with my little brother, as we always did, keeping an eye on him like Mom asked. He was chattering about his day, and I was half-listening, half-thinking about my next client at the salon. When we reached the corner, my phone buzzed—a message from the receptionist: my 3:30 appointment, a first-time visitor, was upset about her hair color and wanted it fixed immediately. My heart pounded. I knew how important it was to make a good impression, to listen carefully and fix any mistakes. But my brother tugged at my sleeve, reminding me we still had a few blocks to go, and Mom would be furious if I left him alone. I could picture the client’s disappointed face in the mirror, the pressure to make it right, and at the same time, my brother’s small hand in mine, trusting me to get him home safe. I stood at the crosswalk, torn between the urgent call of my job and the silent promise I’d made to my family.
